page.title: 05NAVIGATION DOWNDERRY
page.content: FROM THE LAND THIS IS AMONG THE MOST ACCESSIBLE BEACHES IN THE AREA.THERE IS NO HARBOUR BUT A NATURAL REEF, WHICH DRIES AT LOW WATER,PROTECTS THE {BOATPOOL}TO THE ADVANTAGE OF BOATMEN AND SWIMMERS.THE SEAWARD APPROACH IS VIA RECOGNISED CHANNELS IDENTIFIED BY LAND MARKS.NO DEEP DRAUGHT VESSEL CAN NEAR THE SHORE.BEFORE ROADS,BARGES USED TO DELIVER FARM AND BUILDING MATERIALS ON THE HIGH TIDES.THE{GYPSY ONCE A FAMOUS TEACLIPPER WAS WRECKED ON THE {BAR}IN 1901.SPARS FROM THIS AND OTHER WRECKS MAY BE FOUND AS LINTELS IN OLDER HOUSES.DIVING ON THESE WRECKS FOR FISH AND ARTIFACTS IS FAVOURED BY LOCAL & VISITING {SCUBA} DIVERS.IN FINE WEATHER LOCAL BOATS MAY BE LEFT ANCHORED OFFSHORE.IN SUMMER GALES MOST CRAFT ARE HAULED ASHORE TO LINE THE BEACH ROADS.THE TWO LARGER BOATS ARE SAILED TO LOOE HARBOUR.
